concepts.concept_name: Distance, displacement, and types of motion
Speed, velocity, and their differences
Uniform and non-uniform motion, acceleration
Equations of motion and graphical representation
Uniform circular motion

in_scope: Motion along a straight line
Distance: total path length (scalar)
Displacement: shortest path between two points (vector)
Speed = Distance / Time (scalar)
Velocity = Displacement / Time (vector)
Average speed and average velocity
Uniform motion: equal distances in equal time intervals
Non-uniform motion: unequal distances in equal time intervals
Acceleration = Change in velocity / Time
Positive, negative, and zero acceleration
First equation: v = u + at
Second equation: s = ut + ½at²
Third equation: v² = u² + 2as
Distance-time graphs for uniform and non-uniform motion
Velocity-time graphs: area under curve gives distance
Uniform circular motion: constant speed, changing direction
Centripetal acceleration concept
out_of_scope: Basic speed and distance concepts — Covered in Class 7-8
Projectile motion — Introduced in Class 11
Relative motion — Introduced in Class 11
Calculus-based derivations — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Balanced and unbalanced forces
Newton's first law of motion and inertia
Newton's second law of motion (F = ma)
Newton's third law of motion and action-reaction pairs
Conservation of momentum

in_scope: Balanced forces: net force is zero, no change in motion
Unbalanced forces: net force is non-zero, causes acceleration
Newton's first law: body at rest stays at rest, body in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by external force
Inertia: tendency to resist change in state of motion
Types of inertia: inertia of rest, motion, and direction
Mass as a measure of inertia
Newton's second law: F = ma
SI unit of force: Newton (N) = kg·m/s²
Momentum: p = mv, SI unit kg·m/s
Newton's third law: every action has an equal and opposite reaction
Action-reaction pairs act on different bodies
Conservation of momentum in collisions
Applications: recoil of gun, rocket propulsion, walking
out_of_scope: Basic force concepts only — Covered in Class 8
Friction calculations — Covered separately in Class 8 ICSE
Impulse and impulsive forces — Introduced in Class 11
Non-inertial frames of reference — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Universal law of gravitation
Acceleration due to gravity and free fall
Mass and weight
Thrust, pressure, and pressure in fluids
Buoyancy and Archimedes' principle

in_scope: Newton's universal law of gravitation: F = Gm₁m₂/r²
Gravitational constant G = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²
Free fall: motion under gravity alone
Acceleration due to gravity g = 9.8 m/s²
Equations of motion for free fall (replace a with g)
Mass: amount of matter (constant everywhere)
Weight: force of gravity on an object, W = mg
Weight varies with location, mass does not
Weight on moon = 1/6 of weight on earth
Thrust: force perpendicular to a surface
Pressure = Thrust / Area
Pressure in fluids: increases with depth
Buoyancy: upward force by fluid on submerged object
Archimedes' principle: buoyant force = weight of displaced fluid
Conditions for floating and sinking
Relative density = Density of substance / Density of water
out_of_scope: Basic gravity and weight concepts — Covered in Class 7-8
Gravitational field strength — Introduced in Class 11
Kepler's laws — Introduced in Class 11
Variation of g with altitude and depth — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Scientific definition of work and conditions for work
Kinetic energy and its formula
Potential energy and its formula
Law of conservation of energy and energy transformations
Power and commercial unit of energy

in_scope: Work = Force × Displacement × cos θ
Work done is zero when displacement is zero or force is perpendicular to displacement
SI unit of work: Joule (J)
Positive work, negative work, and zero work
Kinetic energy: energy of a body in motion
KE = ½mv²
Work-energy theorem: work done = change in kinetic energy
Potential energy: energy due to position or configuration
Gravitational PE = mgh
Law of conservation of energy: energy can neither be created nor destroyed
Energy transformations in everyday examples
Free-falling body: PE converts to KE
Power = Work / Time = Energy / Time
SI unit of power: Watt (W)
Commercial unit of energy: kilowatt-hour (kWh)
out_of_scope: Basic work and energy concepts — Covered in Class 8
Elastic and inelastic collisions — Introduced in Class 11
Work done by variable force — Introduced in Class 11
Rotational kinetic energy — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Production and propagation of sound
Characteristics of sound: frequency, amplitude, wavelength, speed
Reflection of sound, echo, and reverberation
Range of hearing, ultrasound, and infrasound
Structure of human ear and applications of sound

in_scope: Sound is produced by vibrating objects
Sound requires a material medium for propagation
Sound travels as longitudinal waves: compressions and rarefactions
Speed of sound: solid > liquid > gas
Speed of sound in air at 20°C ≈ 344 m/s
Frequency: number of oscillations per second, unit Hz
Time period: T = 1/f
Wavelength: distance between two consecutive compressions or rarefactions
v = fλ (speed = frequency × wavelength)
Amplitude determines loudness
Frequency determines pitch
Reflection of sound obeys same laws as light
Echo: reflected sound heard after original sound
Minimum distance for echo = 17.2 m (at 20°C in air)
Reverberation: persistence of sound due to multiple reflections
Audible range: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz
Infrasound: below 20 Hz
Ultrasound: above 20,000 Hz
Applications of ultrasound: SONAR, medical imaging, cleaning
Structure of human ear: outer ear, middle ear, inner ear
Eardrum vibrates to convert sound to signals
out_of_scope: Basic sound concepts — Covered in Class 8
Doppler effect — Introduced in Class 11
Standing waves and resonance — Introduced in Class 11
Intensity and decibel scale calculations — Introduced in Class 11
